questions.title: Square Wave Odd Harmonics
questions.question_text: A $50\,\text{Hz}$ square wave with 50% duty cycle contains harmonics at:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! 50% duty square waves have odd harmonics: $f_0, 3f_0, 5f_0... = 50\,\text{Hz}, 150\,\text{Hz}, 250\,\text{Hz}, 350\,\text{Hz}...$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Symmetric square waves contain only odd harmonics at frequencies $f_n = (2k+1)f_0$.

questions.title: Triangle Wave Harmonic Decay
questions.question_text: Triangle waves have harmonic amplitudes that decay as:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Triangle wave Fourier series: $x(t) = (8A/\pi^2)\sum[\sin(2\pi n f_0 t)/n^2]$ for odd $n$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Triangle waves have $1/n^2$ harmonic amplitude decay, faster than square waves ($1/n$).

questions.title: Sawtooth Wave Harmonic Content
questions.question_text: A sawtooth wave with $f_0 = 200\,\text{Hz}$ contains both even and odd harmonics. Calculate the frequency of the 4th harmonic in $\text{Hz}$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! 4th harmonic: $f_4 = 4 \times f_0 = 4 \times 200\,\text{Hz} = 800\,\text{Hz}$. Sawtooth waves have all integer harmonics.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Sawtooth harmonics: $f_n = n \times f_0$ for all integers $n$. $f_4 = 4 \times 200\,\text{Hz} = 800\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.title: Phase Relationships in Harmonics
questions.question_text: In a square wave Fourier series, all harmonic components have:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Square wave harmonics are in-phase: $x(t) = (4A/\pi)\sum[\sin(2\pi n f_0 t)]$ with $\phi_n = 0$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Symmetric square waves have all harmonic components starting in-phase (zero phase).

questions.title: Bandwidth Calculation
questions.question_text: A square wave contains significant harmonics up to the 9th harmonic. If $f_0 = 1\,\text{kHz}$, calculate the signal bandwidth in $\text{kHz}$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Bandwidth $\approx$ highest significant harmonic = $9 \times f_0 = 9 \times 1\,\text{kHz} = 9\,\text{kHz}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Signal bandwidth extends to highest significant harmonic frequency: $\text{BW} = 9 \times 1\,\text{kHz} = 9\,\text{kHz}$.

questions.title: Fourier Series Convergence
questions.question_text: The rate of Fourier series convergence for different waveforms is:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Smoother waveforms converge faster: Sine (1 term) > Triangle ($1/n^2$) > Square ($1/n$).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Convergence rate depends on waveform smoothness: fewer discontinuities enable faster convergence.

questions.title: MATLAB FFT Function Implementation
questions.question_text: In MATLAB, which function transforms a signal $x(t)$ from time domain to frequency domain $X(\omega)$?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! The $\text{fft()}$ function computes the Fast Fourier Transform: $X[k] = \sum x[n]e^{-j2\pi kn/N}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: MATLAB uses $\text{fft()}$ for discrete Fourier transform computation, implementing the Cooley-Tukey algorithm.

questions.title: FFT Post-Processing Requirements
questions.question_text: After computing $Y = \text{fft}(x)$ in MATLAB, additional processing steps are required for proper frequency spectrum visualization.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Post-processing includes: magnitude calculation $|Y|$, normalization, frequency axis creation, and symmetry handling.
questions.feedback_incorrect: FFT output requires magnitude extraction, scaling, and frequency vector generation for meaningful display.

questions.title: Nyquist Frequency Calculation
questions.question_text: For a signal sampled at $f_s = 1000\,\text{Hz}$, calculate the Nyquist frequency $f_N = f_s/2$ in $\text{Hz}$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Nyquist frequency: $f_N = f_s/2 = 1000\,\text{Hz}/2 = 500\,\text{Hz}$ represents the maximum accurately representable frequency.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Nyquist frequency is half the sampling rate: $f_N = f_s/2 = 1000/2 = 500\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.title: FFT Acronym Definition
questions.question_text: The acronym FFT in MATLAB stands for \_\_\_\_\_\_\_ Fourier Transform.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! FFT = Fast Fourier Transform, an efficient $O(N \log N)$ algorithm for computing the DFT.
questions.feedback_incorrect: FFT stands for Fast Fourier Transform, developed by Cooley and Tukey for efficient DFT computation.

questions.title: Frequency Resolution Calculation
questions.question_text: With sampling frequency $f_s = 1000\,\text{Hz}$ and $N = 1000$ samples, calculate the frequency resolution $\Delta f = f_s/N$ in $\text{Hz}$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Frequency resolution: $\Delta f = f_s/N = 1000\,\text{Hz}/1000 = 1\,\text{Hz}$ determines spectral line spacing.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Frequency resolution formula: $\Delta f = f_s/N = 1000\,\text{Hz}/1000\,\text{samples} = 1\,\text{Hz}$ per bin.

questions.title: FFT Magnitude Extraction
questions.question_text: After $Y = \text{fft}(x)$, why apply $\text{abs}(Y)$ in MATLAB signal processing?
questions.correct_answer: Extract magnitude from complex FFT output
choices: Extract magnitude from complex FFT output
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $\text{abs}(Y)$ computes magnitude $|Y[k]| = \sqrt{\text{Re}[Y[k]]^2 + \text{Im}[Y[k]]^2}$ from complex FFT output.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The $\text{abs()}$ function extracts magnitude information from complex-valued FFT coefficients.

questions.title: FFT Length Impact on Resolution
questions.question_text: Increasing FFT length $N$ with fixed sampling rate $f_s$ affects:
questions.correct_answer: Frequency resolution improves: $\Delta f = f_s/N$ decreases
choices: Frequency resolution improves: $\Delta f = f_s/N$ decreases
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Longer FFT improves resolution: $\Delta f = f_s/N$, providing finer frequency discrimination.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Increasing $N$ with fixed $f_s$ reduces $\Delta f = f_s/N$, improving frequency resolution and spectral detail.

questions.title: Signal Length and FFT Accuracy
questions.question_text: Longer time-domain signals always guarantee more accurate frequency domain representations in MATLAB FFT analysis.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Longer signals improve resolution but accuracy depends on stationarity, windowing, and signal characteristics.
questions.feedback_incorrect: FFT accuracy depends on signal properties, windowing effects, and spectral leakage, not just length.

questions.title: Frequency Index Interpretation
questions.question_text: For FFT peak at index $k = 10$, with $f_s = 800\,\text{Hz}$ and $N = 400$ samples, calculate the corresponding frequency in $\text{Hz}$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Frequency = $k \times (f_s/N) = 10 \times (800\,\text{Hz}/400) = 10 \times 2\,\text{Hz} = 20\,\text{Hz}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use frequency mapping: $f = k \times \Delta f = k \times (f_s/N) = 10 \times (800/400) = 20\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.title: FFT Length vs Signal Length
questions.question_text: In MATLAB FFT implementation, the relationship between input signal length and FFT output length is:
questions.correct_answer: FFT length typically equals signal length
choices: FFT length typically equals signal length
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! By default, $\text{fft}(x)$ produces $N$-point FFT where $N = \text{length}(x)$, though zero-padding can extend length.
questions.feedback_incorrect: MATLAB $\text{fft()}$ typically matches input length, though zero-padding enables longer FFTs for improved resolution.

questions.title: Fourier Transform Mathematical Purpose
questions.question_text: The Fourier Transform $F\{x(t)\} = X(\omega)$ mathematically accomplishes:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Fourier Transform: $X(\omega) = \int x(t)e^{-j\omega t}dt$ decomposes signals into frequency components.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The Fourier Transform reveals spectral composition by converting temporal signals to frequency domain.

questions.title: Non-Standard Fourier Applications
questions.question_text: Which application does NOT typically utilize Fourier Transform analysis?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Instantaneous measurements are time-domain tasks; Fourier analysis reveals frequency content over time intervals.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Fourier Transform analyzes frequency content, not instantaneous time-domain measurements.

questions.title: Fourier Transform Signal Compatibility
questions.question_text: The Fourier Transform mathematical framework applies to:
questions.correct_answer: Both simple and complex signal types
choices: Both simple and complex signal types
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Fourier analysis applies to any integrable function: periodic, aperiodic, continuous, or discrete signals.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Fourier Transform is universally applicable to various signal types through different formulations (CTFT, DTFT, DFT).

questions.title: Fourier Analysis Signal Processing Impact
questions.question_text: Fourier analysis fundamentally enables:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Fourier analysis is foundational for spectral analysis, filtering, modulation, and frequency-domain processing.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Fourier analysis underlies most signal processing: spectral analysis, filtering, convolution via multiplication, etc.

questions.title: Fourier Transform Computational Challenges
questions.question_text: Primary limitations of Fourier Transform implementation include:
questions.correct_answer: Both non-periodic representation and computational demands
choices: Both non-periodic representation and computational demands
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Fourier assumes periodicity and DFT has $O(N^2)$ complexity (reduced to $O(N \log N)$ with FFT).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Fourier Transform challenges: spectral leakage for non-periodic signals and computational complexity for large datasets.

questions.title: Fourier Transform Output Generation
questions.question_text: The Fourier Transform $F\{x(t)\} = X(\omega) = \int x(t)e^{-j\omega t}dt$ directly enables creation of:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Fourier Transform produces complex spectrum $X(\omega)$, enabling frequency spectrum visualization $|X(\omega)|$ vs $\omega$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The Fourier Transform converts time signals to frequency domain, creating spectral representations.

questions.title: Fourier Transform Information Content
questions.question_text: From Fourier Transform output $X(\omega) = |X(\omega)|e^{j\phi(\omega)}$, you can determine:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $|X(\omega)|$ reveals frequency component magnitudes, showing which frequencies dominate the signal.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Fourier Transform magnitude $|X(\omega)|$ indicates the strength or amplitude of each frequency component.

questions.title: Domain Transformation Definition
questions.question_text: The Fourier Transform converts signals from time domain $x(t)$ to \_\_\_\_\_\_\_ domain $X(\omega)$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Fourier Transform: $x(t) \to X(\omega)$ transforms temporal signals into frequency domain representations.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The fundamental purpose of Fourier Transform is time-to-frequency domain conversion.

questions.title: Frequency Spectrum Amplitude
questions.question_text: The frequency spectrum displays the \_\_\_\_\_\_\_ $|X(\omega)|$ of different frequency components $\omega$ in signal $x(t)$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Frequency spectrum plots magnitude $|X(\omega)|$ showing amplitude distribution across frequencies.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The frequency spectrum visualizes how signal amplitude varies with frequency components.

questions.title: Complex Signal Decomposition
questions.question_text: Complex signals like music contain multiple frequency \_\_\_\_\_\_\_ that Fourier Transform can separate and analyze.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Fourier analysis decomposes complex signals into constituent frequency components or harmonics.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Complex signals are composed of multiple frequency components that can be isolated using Fourier analysis.

questions.title: Filter Design Application
questions.question_text: Frequency domain analysis using Fourier Transform enables engineers to design:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Filter design uses frequency response $H(\omega) = Y(\omega)/X(\omega)$ based on Fourier domain specifications.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Fourier analysis is fundamental for designing filters that selectively pass or reject frequency bands.

questions.title: Inverse Transform Operation
questions.question_text: To convert frequency domain $X(\omega)$ back to time domain $x(t)$, apply the \_\_\_\_\_\_\_ Fourier Transform.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Inverse Fourier Transform: $x(t) = (1/2\pi)\int X(\omega)e^{j\omega t}d\omega$ reconstructs time signals.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The Inverse Fourier Transform reverses the frequency-to-time domain conversion process.

questions.title: Phase and Magnitude Information
questions.question_text: Fourier Transform output $X(\omega) = |X(\omega)|e^{j\phi(\omega)}$ provides both amplitude $|X(\omega)|$ and:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Complex Fourier output contains magnitude $|X(\omega)|$ and phase $\phi(\omega) = \text{arg}(X(\omega))$ information.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Fourier Transform provides complete spectral information: both magnitude and phase for each frequency.

questions.title: Periodic Signal Analysis Suitability
questions.question_text: Fourier Transform analysis is particularly effective for periodic signals due to their well-defined frequency content.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Periodic signals have discrete frequency spectra, making Fourier analysis highly effective for characterization.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Periodic signals with fundamental frequency $f_0$ and harmonics $nf_0$ are ideally suited for Fourier analysis.

questions.title: Dominant Frequency Identification
questions.question_text: In frequency spectrum analysis, dominant frequencies correspond to peaks with highest \_\_\_\_\_\_\_ values $|X(\omega)|$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Spectral peaks with maximum $|X(\omega)|$ indicate dominant frequency components in the signal.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Large amplitude values in frequency spectrum indicate strong, dominant frequency components.

questions.title: Comprehensive Fourier Analysis Explanation
questions.question_text: Fourier Transform decomposes signals into sinusoids via $X(\omega) = \int x(t)e^{-j\omega t}dt$. A practical application is:
questions.correct_answer: Audio equalization for frequency band adjustment
choices: Audio equalization for frequency band adjustment
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Audio equalizers use Fourier analysis to identify and adjust specific frequency bands in music and speech.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Audio equalization exemplifies Fourier analysis: identifying frequency content for selective amplification or attenuation.

questions.title: Primary Fourier Transform Purpose
questions.question_text: The fundamental purpose of Fourier Transform in signal analysis is:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Fourier Transform reveals frequency composition through domain transformation: $x(t) \to X(\omega)$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The primary function is mathematical transformation from temporal to spectral representation.

questions.title: Non-Typical Fourier Applications
questions.question_text: Which application does NOT typically require Fourier Transform analysis?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Instantaneous measurements are time-domain operations; Fourier analysis reveals frequency content over intervals.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Fourier Transform analyzes frequency content, not instantaneous time-domain measurements.

questions.title: Information Limitations in Fourier Analysis
questions.question_text: Standard Fourier Transform $X(\omega)$ does NOT directly provide:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Fourier Transform provides global frequency information but sacrifices temporal localization (uncertainty principle).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Standard Fourier analysis loses time information; Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT) provides time-frequency analysis.

questions.title: Signal Processing Contributions
questions.question_text: Fourier analysis enables signal processing through:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Fourier analysis underlies spectral analysis, filtering, convolution, modulation, and frequency domain processing.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Fourier Transform is foundational for virtually all frequency-based signal processing operations.

questions.title: Domain Conversion Definition
questions.question_text: The Fourier Transform converts signals from time domain $x(t)$ to \_\_\_\_\_\_\_ domain $X(\omega)$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Fourier Transform performs time-to-frequency domain conversion: $x(t) \leftrightarrow X(\omega)$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The fundamental operation transforms temporal signals into their frequency domain representations.

questions.title: Frequency Spectrum Representation
questions.question_text: The frequency spectrum displays the \_\_\_\_\_\_\_ $|X(\omega)|$ of different frequency components in signal $x(t)$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Frequency spectrum plots magnitude $|X(\omega)|$ showing amplitude distribution across frequencies $\omega$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The spectrum visualizes how signal amplitudes vary across different frequency components.

questions.title: Complex Signal Decomposition
questions.question_text: Complex signals like music decompose into constituent frequency \_\_\_\_\_\_\_ through Fourier Transform analysis.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Fourier analysis separates complex waveforms into individual frequency components or harmonics.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Complex signals contain multiple frequency components that can be identified using Fourier analysis.

questions.title: Time Domain Reconstruction
questions.question_text: To convert frequency domain $X(\omega)$ back to time domain $x(t)$, apply the \_\_\_\_\_\_\_ Fourier Transform.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Inverse Fourier Transform: $x(t) = F^{-1}\{X(\omega)\}$ reverses the frequency-to-time conversion.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The Inverse Fourier Transform reconstructs time-domain signals from frequency domain data.

questions.title: Periodic Signal Analysis Effectiveness
questions.question_text: Fourier Transform is particularly effective for periodic signals due to their discrete \_\_\_\_\_\_\_ content.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Periodic signals have well-defined frequency spectra with discrete components at harmonics.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Periodic signals with fundamental frequency $f_0$ and harmonics create clear spectral lines.

questions.title: Dominant Frequency Identification
questions.question_text: In frequency spectrum analysis, dominant frequencies appear as peaks with maximum \_\_\_\_\_\_\_ $|X(\omega)|$ values.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Spectral peaks with highest $|X(\omega)|$ indicate the strongest frequency components.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Large amplitude values in the spectrum correspond to dominant frequency components.

questions.title: Comprehensive Fourier Transform Application
questions.question_text: Fourier Transform decomposes $x(t)$ into sinusoids via $X(\omega) = \int x(t)e^{-j\omega t}dt$. Real-world application:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Audio equalizers use Fourier analysis to identify and selectively boost/cut frequency bands.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Audio equalization demonstrates practical Fourier analysis: spectral identification for frequency-specific processing.

questions.title: Dominant Frequency Peak Identification
questions.question_text: In a frequency spectrum with a clear peak at $f = 1\,\text{kHz}$, the dominant frequency component is:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! The dominant frequency corresponds to the highest amplitude peak in the spectrum.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Dominant frequencies are identified by locating the maximum amplitude peaks in the spectrum.

questions.title: Multi-Component Spectrum Analysis
questions.question_text: A frequency spectrum displaying multiple distinct peaks indicates:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Multiple peaks indicate superposition of different frequency components in the original signal.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Each spectral peak represents a distinct frequency component in the complex signal.

questions.title: Single Peak Spectrum Interpretation
questions.question_text: A frequency spectrum with one sharp peak most likely represents:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Single spectral peak indicates a pure sinusoidal tone at that frequency.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Pure sine waves produce single-frequency spectra with one dominant peak.

questions.title: Harmonic Pattern Recognition
questions.question_text: Evenly spaced spectral peaks at frequencies $f_0, 2f_0, 3f_0, 4f_0...$ indicate:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Harmonic series appears as evenly spaced peaks at integer multiples of fundamental frequency $f_0$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Periodic signals generate harmonic spectra with peaks at $nf_0$ where $n = 1, 2, 3, ...$

questions.title: Noise Spectrum Characteristics
questions.question_text: A broad, flat spectral region across frequencies typically indicates:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Broadband noise exhibits flat spectral density across wide frequency ranges.
questions.feedback_incorrect: White noise and random signals appear as relatively flat, broad spectral distributions.

questions.title: Spectral Peak Height Interpretation
questions.question_text: Varying peak heights in frequency spectrum $|X(\omega)|$ represent:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Peak height directly corresponds to $|X(\omega)|$, the amplitude of each frequency component.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Spectral magnitude $|X(\omega)|$ shows the relative amplitudes of different frequency components.

questions.title: SI Unit for Electric Charge
questions.question_text: What is the standard SI unit used to measure electric charge?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! The Coulomb (C) is the SI base unit for electric charge, defined as the charge transported by 1A of current in 1s.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Remember: V measures voltage, A measures current, $\Omega$ measures resistance. The Coulomb (C) measures charge.

questions.title: Elementary Charge Magnitude
questions.question_text: The elementary charge $e$ represents the fundamental unit of electric charge. What is its approximate magnitude?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $e = 1.602 \times 10^{-19}\ \text{C}$ is the magnitude of charge on a proton ($+e$) or electron ($-e$).
questions.feedback_incorrect: The elementary charge $e = 1.602 \times 10^{-19}\ \text{C}$. Note: $6.02 \times 10^{23}$ is Avogadro's number, $9.11 \times 10^{-31}$ is electron mass.

questions.title: Current Definition
questions.question_text: Electric current $I$ is fundamentally defined as the rate of flow of electric charge. What creates current in a conductor?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Current $I = dQ/dt$ represents moving charges (electrons in metals, ions in electrolytes).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Current requires charge motion. Static fields don't create current; magnetic fields alone don't move charges.

questions.title: Coulomb's Law Force Characteristics
questions.question_text: Coulomb's Law $F = k_0q_1q_2/r^2$ describes electrostatic force. Unlike gravitational force, electric force can:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Electric force is attractive for opposite charges ($\pm$) and repulsive for like charges ($++,--$).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Electric forces depend on charge signs: opposite charges attract, like charges repel. Gravity only attracts.

questions.title: Electrostatics Field Sources
questions.question_text: Electrostatics analyzes electric fields $\vec{E}$ created by which type of charge distributions?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Electrostatics deals with stationary charges ($\partial\rho/\partial t = 0$), where $\rho$ is charge density.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Electrostatics assumes static charges. Time-varying currents and accelerating charges belong to electrodynamics.
